AES.name: Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)
AES.description: Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) is a symmetric block cipher developed by NIST in 2001. It encrypts data in fixed-size blocks using key sizes of 128, 192, or 256 bits. AES is efficient, secure, and widely used in applications like VPNs, HTTPS, and file encryption.
AES.advantages: Strong security, fast performance, widely supported.
AES.disadvantages: Complex implementation, vulnerable if weak key management.
AES.applications: Used in SSL/TLS, Wi-Fi (WPA2/WPA3), disk encryption, and secure communications.

DES.name: Data Encryption Standard (DES)
DES.description: Data Encryption Standard (DES) is a symmetric-key block cipher developed in the 1970s by IBM and adopted by NIST. It uses a 56-bit key and operates on 64-bit data blocks. DES is now considered insecure due to its short key length.
DES.disadvantages: Vulnerable to brute-force attacks; outdated for modern use.
DES.applications: Historically used in financial systems and early network encryption.

DES3.name: Triple Data Encryption Standard (3DES)
DES3.description: Triple DES (3DES) is an enhancement of DES that applies the DES algorithm three times to each data block using either two or three keys. It increases security compared to DES but is slower.
DES3.advantages: More secure than DES, easy migration for systems using DES.
DES3.disadvantages: Slower performance, now considered weak compared to AES.
DES3.applications: Used in legacy systems, smart cards, and older banking systems.

CAST-128.name: CAST-128 (CAST5)
CAST-128.description: CAST-128, also known as CAST5, is a symmetric block cipher using a 64-bit block size and variable key sizes from 40 to 128 bits. It is known for its speed and security.
CAST-128.advantages: Flexible key size, strong against differential cryptanalysis.
CAST-128.disadvantages: Limited to 64-bit block size, replaced by AES in modern systems.
CAST-128.applications: Used in PGP encryption and network security applications.

ChaCha20.name: ChaCha20 Stream Cipher
ChaCha20.description: ChaCha20 is a modern stream cipher designed by Daniel J. Bernstein. It improves upon Salsa20 with better diffusion and security. It operates efficiently on both hardware and software, making it popular in TLS and mobile encryption.
ChaCha20.advantages: High performance, resistant to timing attacks, secure.
ChaCha20.disadvantages: Requires nonce reuse protection; not suitable for all legacy systems.
ChaCha20.applications: Used in TLS 1.3, SSH, Google’s QUIC protocol, and VPNs.

ECB.name: Electronic Code Book (ECB)
ECB.description: ECB is the simplest mode of operation for block ciphers. Each plaintext block is encrypted separately using the same key. Identical plaintext blocks produce identical ciphertexts, making patterns visible.
ECB.disadvantages: Insecure for large or repetitive data; reveals patterns.
ECB.applications: Used for encrypting small amounts of random data or keys.

CBC.name: Cipher Block Chaining (CBC)
CBC.description: CBC mode chains each block of ciphertext with the previous one using XOR, providing better security. It requires an initialization vector (IV) for the first block.
CBC.advantages: More secure than ECB, hides plaintext patterns.
CBC.disadvantages: Errors propagate; requires IV; slower in parallel processing.
CBC.applications: Used in TLS, SSH, and file encryption.

CFB.name: Cipher Feedback (CFB)
CFB.description: CFB mode turns a block cipher into a self-synchronizing stream cipher. It encrypts smaller segments of plaintext and uses the previous ciphertext block for the next step.
CFB.advantages: Can process data in small chunks; self-synchronizing.
CFB.applications: Used in secure data streams and partial data encryption.

OFB.name: Output Feedback (OFB)
OFB.description: OFB converts a block cipher into a synchronous stream cipher. It generates keystream blocks independent of plaintext and XORs them with the data.
OFB.advantages: No error propagation; good for noisy channels.
OFB.disadvantages: Requires careful IV management; not parallelizable.
OFB.applications: Used in satellite and wireless communications.

CTR.name: Counter (CTR)
CTR.description: CTR mode turns a block cipher into a stream cipher by encrypting successive counter values and XORing them with plaintext. It allows parallel encryption and decryption.
CTR.applications: Used in VPNs, disk encryption, and TLS.

EAX.name: EAX Mode
EAX.description: EAX is an authenticated encryption mode that provides both confidentiality and integrity using CTR mode for encryption and CMAC for authentication.
EAX.disadvantages: Slightly slower due to additional authentication step.
EAX.applications: Used in secure file and message encryption.

GCM.name: Galois/Counter Mode (GCM)
GCM.description: GCM is an authenticated encryption mode combining CTR for encryption and Galois field multiplication for authentication. It is efficient and widely used.
GCM.applications: Used in HTTPS, IPsec, and TLS 1.3.

CCM.name: Counter with CBC-MAC (CCM)
CCM.description: CCM mode combines CTR mode for encryption and CBC-MAC for authentication, providing both confidentiality and integrity.
CCM.applications: Used in Wi-Fi (WPA2), Bluetooth, and IoT devices.

SIV.name: Synthetic IV (SIV)
SIV.description: SIV mode prevents nonce misuse by generating a synthetic IV based on the plaintext and key. Even if a nonce is reused, it maintains security.
SIV.applications: Used in high-security protocols where nonce reuse risk exists.

OCB.name: Offset Codebook Mode (OCB)
OCB.description: OCB mode provides authenticated encryption in a single pass, combining confidentiality and authenticity efficiently.

ChaCha20_Poly1305.name: ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD
ChaCha20_Poly1305.description: ChaCha20-Poly1305 is an authenticated encryption algorithm that combines the ChaCha20 cipher with the Poly1305 authenticator. It provides both confidentiality and integrity.
ChaCha20_Poly1305.advantages: High speed, secure, resistant to side-channel attacks.
ChaCha20_Poly1305.applications: Used in TLS 1.3, SSH, and Google Chrome's HTTPS encryption.
